resources.string: How do we calculate \n your carbon footprint?
Your carbon footprint is calculated with the amount of greenhouse gasses you released throughout one year.

We calculate your carbon footprint by looking at several factors. First, we look at your utilities and transport expenses; buying gas and taking the car makes your score go down. We also look at your purchasing habits to see if you make environmentally conscious choices.

To reduce your consumption, therefore both helping the environment and your own wallet by limiting your expenses, you should always bring a bag to the store. Furthermore, it is a good idea to turn the A/C off when leaving the house, as it can be a quick energy and money sink without being noticed.

To buy the right produce, it is important to keep in mind that each of them has its season. When you buy produce that is off-season, it will require a lot of transport to get to your grocery store. This increases the price, as the costs need to be offset, as well as negatively impacts the environment.

When you take into account the environmental cost of your everyday choices, you also start to realize all the opportunities for good that occur in your everyday life. Simply bringing a reusable bag and keeping an eye out for seasonal fruits and vegetables is a way of not only saving money (those five cents add up!) but also of positively impacting the earth.
